Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action under Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 212, § 4 because Plaintiff seeks monetary damages well in excess of $25,000 as compensation for injuries sustained due to Defendant's negligent acts.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 223, § 1, as the alleged incident occurred in Pittsfield, Massachusetts, Berkshire County, and Defendant resides and conducts activities there.

Yallop v. Prime Bank of Mass., 59 Mass..raw_text: Yallop v. Prime Bank of Mass., 59 Mass. App. Ct. 111 (2003)
Yallop v. Prime Bank of Mass., 59 Mass..proposition: Yallop v. Prime Bank of Mass., 59 Mass. App. Ct. 111 (2003) (defining duty of reasonable care owed by property owners).
Yallop v. Prime Bank of Mass., 59 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns drug trafficking, joint venture liability, sufficiency of evidence, grand jury probable cause, suppression, and jury selection. It does not involve premises liability, negligence, or any definition of a duty of reasonable care owed by property owners. Accordingly, it does not support a proposition about defining that duty; the citation is misplaced for that purpose.
Yallop v. Prime Bank of Mass., 59 Mass..relevant_excerpt: We summarize the evidence presented to the grand jury on the indictment. A State police trooper testified that when he entered the apartment Arango was seated in the kitchen with a cutting agent used in distributing cocaine in plain view. Nearby the trooper found another cutting agent used in distributing drugs. He also testified to finding in the apartment other accoutrements of drug distribution activity, such as cell phones, beepers, a drug ledger, and cash.

Davis v. Westwood Grp., 420 Mass. 739 (1.proposition: Davis v. Westwood Grp., 420 Mass. 739 (1995) (establishing standard duty to maintain property in safe condition).
Davis v. Westwood Grp., 420 Mass. 739 (1.support_reasoning: The court expressly states the general common-law rule that an owner or possessor of land owes lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care, including maintaining the premises in a reasonably safe condition and warning of unreasonable dangers. Although the holding focuses on limiting a landowner’s duty regarding adjacent state highways, the opinion clearly articulates and reaffirms the standard duty to maintain property in a safe condition. Thus, it is a proper citation for that general duty proposition.
Davis v. Westwood Grp., 420 Mass. 739 (1.relevant_excerpt: “It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. … This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware.”

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368 (2010) (landowners can be held liable for harm resulting from failing to address known hazards).
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion expressly holds that landowners owe lawful visitors a general duty of reasonable care with respect to hazards from snow and ice, just like any other hazard on the property. That duty is framed in terms of knowing or having reason to know of a dangerous condition and making reasonable efforts to protect visitors, which encompasses liability for failing to address known hazards. The court abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation limitation and replaces it with a straightforward reasonable-care standard for known dangers on the land.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.’ … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973) (abolishing distinctions between invitees and licensees for premises liability cases).
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: Mounsey is a landmark Massachusetts case that explicitly abolishes the common‑law distinction between invitees and licensees in premises liability, imposing instead a general duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. The quoted concurrence by Justice Kaplan criticizes the court’s retention of a separate category for trespassers, which presupposes that the main opinion has in fact eliminated the invitee/licensee distinction. Thus, the case is properly cited for the proposition that Massachusetts no longer distinguishes between invitees and licensees for premises liability purposes.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt:
(Majority opinion, not in the user’s excerpt) “We have concluded that the common law distinctions between invitee and licensee should no longer be followed in this Commonwealth… We therefore hold that the occupier of land owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors.”

(From Kaplan, J., concurring, as quoted): “The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors.”

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 231, § 85 (establishing principles of comparative negligence).

Clohessy v. Gaughan, 352 Mass. 704 (1967.proposition: Clohessy v. Gaughan, 352 Mass. 704 (1967) (duty owed to foreseeable plaintiffs harmed by natural conditions under landowner’s control).

Breen v. Dedham Water Co., 389 Mass. 320.raw_text: Breen v. Dedham Water Co., 389 Mass. 320 (1983)
Breen v. Dedham Water Co., 389 Mass. 320.proposition: Breen v. Dedham Water Co., 389 Mass. 320 (1983) (foreseeability as a key factor in establishing negligence).
Breen v. Dedham Water Co., 389 Mass. 320.support_reasoning: The opinion is a criminal sentencing / constitutional analysis about enhanced penalties for OUI based on prior assignment to an alcohol education program. It does not discuss negligence, duty, breach, or foreseeability as elements of a negligence claim. Nothing in the holding or reasoning treats foreseeability as a key factor in establishing negligence, so citing this case for that proposition would be inaccurate.
Breen v. Dedham Water Co., 389 Mass. 320.relevant_excerpt: We come then to the question whether constitutional principles bar the imposition of enhanced penalties on a person who, having been assigned to an alcohol education program prior to September 1, 1982, is convicted of driving on or after September 1, 1982, while under the influence of intoxicating liquor. The issue involves a question of fundamental fairness in a due process sense. Although the concept underlying the prohibition against ex post facto laws is also based on fundamental fairness, we see no violation of the prohibition against ex post facto laws.

Sanders v. Alger, 427 Mass. 140 (1998).proposition: Sanders v. Alger, 427 Mass. 140 (1998) (importance of actual and constructive notice for landowner liability).
Sanders v. Alger, 427 Mass. 140 (1998).case_name: Bankers Life & Casualty Co. v. Commissioner of Insurance
Sanders v. Alger, 427 Mass. 140 (1998).support_reasoning: The case is an insurance rate‑regulation decision concerning Medicare supplement (Medigap) rates and the Commissioner of Insurance’s authority and methodology. It does not involve premises liability, landowners, or doctrines of actual or constructive notice. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority on the importance of actual and constructive notice for landowner liability; the proposition mischaracterizes the subject matter of the opinion.
Sanders v. Alger, 427 Mass. 140 (1998).relevant_excerpt: “On joint motion of the parties, a single justice of this court reserved and reported without decision the petition of Bankers Life and Casualty Company (Bankers Life) for judicial review of the decision of the Commissioner of Insurance (commissioner) disapproving its request for rate increases for two of its Medicare supplement insurance plans. Bankers Life argues that the commissioner exceeded her authority under G. L. c. 176K, § 7, which governs rate-setting procedures for Medicare supplement insurance policies…”

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.proposition: Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (2013) (recognizing physical harm caused by failure to remediate unsafe land conditions).
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.support_reasoning: The case squarely addresses a landowner’s duty to remedy unsafe conditions on land even when the danger is open and obvious, and it involves serious physical harm resulting from the failure to correct an unsafe trampoline–pool setup. The SJC holds that a landowner is not relieved from remedying such an open and obvious danger where the landowner can and should anticipate that it will cause physical harm, and reverses because the jury were not allowed to consider this duty-to-remedy theory. This directly recognizes physical harm caused by a failure to remediate unsafe land conditions.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.relevant_excerpt: "A landowner, though, 'is not relieved from remedying an open and obvious danger where [the landowner] "can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm to the [lawful visitor] notwithstanding its known or obvious danger."' Papadopoulos, supra, quoting Soederberg... Here, Jose set up a trampoline immediately adjacent to a two-foot-deep pool... In many ways, Jose’s actions were equivalent to installing a diving board in the shallow end of an in-ground pool.... On these facts, a jury were entitled to conclude that the defendants owed a duty of care — specifically a duty to remedy — despite the open and obvious nature of the danger."
